I see some problems with the libertarian ideal being discussed here, in which there wouldn't be a "marriage contract", and the claim it would supposedly lead to equality for same-sex couples.
 
 Marriage was a contract created by a court a long, long, time ago, under British Common-Law tradition. Marriage has also been re-defined by courts in several places, such as Canada and some U.S. states, that use the common-law definition of marriage, to include same-sex couples. How would we go back in time and do away with "marriage" as it stands as part of our legal tradition and current practice?
 
 Also, in reality, marriage gives guarantees that simple contracts do not. I could write up a will, leaving things to my spouse. However, that could be contested by greedy relatives. With the strength of marriage, those greedy relations wouldn't have a leg to stand on. What about insurance and surviving spouse benefits? Without equal marriage, discrimination against same-sex spouses is more likely there. What would I need to ensure I can see my spouse in the hospital? How would I get federal tax benefits, as someone else mentioned? It would take much more trouble and very good financial resources for lawyers, in order to make sure you have a strong contract, or series of contracts. A single, powerful, accessible to all, marriage contract, makes things better and easier.
